title: Confounder Of The Day: How Sexy Your Parents Were
summary:
Key ideas
- Psychiatric disorders are more common in people born of young mothers and old fathers.
- Women with psychiatric disorders can be more impulsive, leading to teenage pregnancy which leads to children at a younger age.
- The child of a 45-year-old father is 1.5x more likely to develop schizophrenia and 1.8x more likely to develop autism compared to the child of a 25-year-old father.
- Mental health of a child depends less on how old her father was when she was born than on how old her father was when he had his first child.
- Mental disorders make it harder for a man to find a partner and start having kids.

Key learnings
- Parents' age can contribute to the risk of psychiatric disorders in children.
- Petersen et al's study suggests that the risk of mental disorders doesn't depend on father's age during the birth of a specific child but rather how old the father was when he had his first child.
- Mental disorders in men can make it harder for them to find partners and start having children.

Key questions
- What are the other factors that contribute to the risks of mental disorders in children?
- Can psychiatric disorders be prevented or treated?
- How can society reduce the stigma that men with mental disorders experience in the dating world?
